Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.raw_text: Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First National Realty Corp., 4.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential leases, which requires the landlord to refrain from actions or omissions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.

Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in residential leases, which requires the landlord to refrain from actions or omissions that substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.support_reasoning: The opinion is a California Supreme Court decision about California common law and the implied warranty of habitability in California residential leases. It mentions the Massachusetts case Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway only as part of a survey of other jurisdictions, but it does not itself interpret or apply Massachusetts law or articulate Massachusetts’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority that Massachusetts law recognizes a particular implied covenant of quiet enjoyment or its contours.
Green v. Superior Court, 10 Cal.3d 616 (.relevant_excerpt: “The Supreme Court of Wisconsin was the first to adopt this approach in 1961, and since 1969 the Supreme Courts of Hawaii, New Jersey, New Hampshire, Illinois, Iowa, and Massachusetts and the Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia have followed this lead. [fn. 12] … 1… Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway (Mass. 1973) 293 N.E.2d 831.”

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: The Commonwealth’s sanitary and housing standards—set forth in the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.)—require that dwelling units be maintained free of vermin and rodent infestations and that landlords take reasonable steps to abate infestations when they affect habitability.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Massachusetts courts and other authorities have held that persistent infestations of vermin or rodents that substantially interfere with a tenant’s reasonable use of the premises may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or the implied warranty of habitability, entitling the tenant to damages and/or equitable relief.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes and applies an implied warranty of habitability and discusses damages for conditions such as sewage, leaks, lack of heat, and general disrepair, but it does not address Massachusetts law on vermin or rodents, nor does it frame such conditions as a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Although the court mentions rodents hypothetically when describing the types of injuries habitability breaches can cause, this is dicta and not tied to the actual facts or holding. Thus, the case supports the broader idea that serious habitability defects can warrant damages, but not specifically that persistent vermin or rodent infestations constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment or habitability under Massachusetts or other authority.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt:
“Damages for annoyance and discomfort are reasonable in light of the fact that

  the residential tenant who has suffered a breach of the warranty . . . cannot bathe as frequently as he would like or at all if there is inadequate hot water; he must worry about rodents harassing his children or spreading disease if the premises are infested; or he must avoid certain rooms or worry about catching a cold if there is inadequate weather protection or heat. Thus, discomfort and annoyance are the common injuries caused by each breach …”

Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.raw_text: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell, 47 N.Y.2d 316 (1979)
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.proposition: Massachusetts courts and other authorities have held that persistent infestations of vermin or rodents that substantially interfere with a tenant’s reasonable use of the premises may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or the implied warranty of habitability, entitling the tenant to damages and/or equitable relief.
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.case_name: Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.support_reasoning: The case is not a Massachusetts decision, but it is explicitly relying on and aligning with Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway and similar authorities in articulating the modern implied warranty of habitability. The New York Court of Appeals squarely states that insect or rodent infestation are conditions that materially affect health and safety and thus fall within a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, entitling tenants to rent abatement. That directly supports the proposition that persistent vermin/rodent infestations substantially interfering with reasonable use can constitute such a breach and warrant damages or equitable relief.
Park West Management Corp. v. Mitchell,.relevant_excerpt: "A residential lease is essentially a sale of shelter and necessarily encompasses those services which render the premises suitable for the purpose for which they are leased. ... he does warrant, however, that there are no conditions that materially affect the health and safety of tenants. For example, no one will dispute that health and safety are adversely affected by insect or rodent infestation, insufficient heat and plumbing facilities, significantly dangerous electrical outlets or wiring, inadequate sanitation facilities or similar services which constitute the essence of the modern dwelling unit."

Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186.raw_text: Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186 (Landlord and Tenant).
Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 186.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s persistent failure to remedy conditions that result in a substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and may entitle the tenant to damages for actual losses, diminution in rental value, and other relief.

Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 111.proposition: The Commonwealth’s sanitary and housing standards—set forth in the State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410.000 et seq.)—require that dwelling units be maintained free of vermin and rodent infestations and that landlords take reasonable steps to abate infestations when they affect habitability.
